PDF image rendering in Author mode

body.p: Starting with version 20.0, PDF images are rendered in Author mode and PDF output. For previous versions, they are not rendered by default. To add such support in previous versions, you need to add the Apache PDFBox library by using one of the following procedures:

section.title: Installing the ApachePDFBox Libraries Add-on
section.p:
offers an add-on that contributes the Apache PDFBox library for you. To install this add-on, follow these steps:
Go to Help Install new add-ons to open an add-on selection dialog box.
Enter or paste https://raw.githubusercontent.com/oxygenxml/oxygenxml.pdfimage/master/addon.xml in the Show add-ons from field.
Select the ApachePDFBox Libraries add-on and click Next.
Select the I accept all terms of the end user license agreement option and click Finish.
Restart the application.
Result: The Apache PDFBox libraries are now contributed to the Oxygen installation directory and you should be able to see PDF images in Author mode.
For more information, see the details about this ApachePDFBox Libraries add-on in GitHub.

section.title: Manually Adding the ApachePDFBox Libraries
section.p:
To manually add the Apache PDFBox library so that PDF images are rendered in Author mode, follow this procedure:
Go to and download the pre-built PDFBox standalone binary JAR files: pdfbox-2.0.3.jar, fontbox-2.0.3.jar, and xmpbox-2.0.3.jar. Alternatively, you can use the 1.8.12 version of these files, as they have been tested and work properly.It is not recommended to use pdfbox-app-2.0.3.jar file instead of the three specified files because it contains additional classes that may cause conflicts elsewhere in .
Create a subfolder called pdfImageJars in the \lib directory.
Copy the downloaded JAR libraries to that newly created subfolder.
Open OXYGEN_PLUGIN_DIR/META-INF/MANIFEST.MF and add a reference to the JAR libraries in the Bundle-ClassPath entry.
Restart the application.Restart Eclipse in clean mode (edit the shortcut you use to start Eclipse and add -clean as the first argument.)
